type

pass types used

size

finish variations
many!

level
beginner


type of wrap
Woven Wrap


characteristics
optionally uses rings


good for
Leaners, Toddlers and Support

title: Double Hammock
text:
Carry Recipe
Base Size – 2 Traditional Sling Passes + 2 Reinforcing Passes

Off center Traditional Sling Pass over baby on back with short tail over shoulder
Spread Chest Pass with long tail
Traditional Sling Pass over baby
Bunched or spread Reinforcing passes over and under baby’s legs
TIF

title: Base Plus 1 Carries
text: Base Size is the defined as the woven wrap size needed to do Front Wrap Cross Carry. Base Size Plus 1 would be one wrap size larger than a wearer’s base. In addition to the carries listed below, adding fancy finishes, using a thick wrap, wrapping a larger child, and other factors may result in the need to use a Base+1 wrap for many Base Size carries.

title: Base Plus 1 Carries
text:
Back Carries

Taiwanese
Torso Double Hammock
Wiggleproof Back Carry (WP)
Double Hammock often requires Base+1 for many wrappers

title: Base Size Carries
text: Base Size is defined as the woven wrap size needed to do Front Wrap Cross Carry. Base Size can be affected by the size of the wearee, wrap thickness, and taper depth. The Base Size Guide provides some guidance for finding one’s Base Size, but the only way to know for sure is to start wrapping!

title: No-Sew Ring Sling
text:
Carry Recipe
No-Sew Ring Sling – Base Size Minus 5 – Traditional Sling Pass

Thread one tail through two rings and back under the outside ring
Place short tail on shoulder with rings in corsage position
Wrap around back and under arm
Thread tail through both rings and back under the outside ring like a normal ring sling

title: No No No Hip Carry
text:
Carry Recipe

Wrap folded over itself at one end and draped over shoulder with short end underneath, making a loop
Wrap draped end around for traditional sling pass
Feed long end through loop and create pouch
Feed baby into pouch
Tighten incrementally through loop
Bunched reinforcing pass over near leg, and under far leg, tuck up into back pass

title: Base Size Guide
text:
Base Size is the defined as the woven wrap size needed to do Front Wrap Cross Carry. Base Size can be affected by the size and shape of the wearer, size of the wearee, wrap thickness, taper depth, tightening ability/preference, how much clothing is being worn by the wearer and wearee, and wrapping qualities of the woven wrap.
For new wearers looking for a starting point, T-shirt size may be used as a rough guide for finding your base size. However, it’s quite common to find your true base is a size above or a size below what is suggested here as there are other factors at play beyond clothing size. The best way to find your actual Base Size is to try Front Wrap Cross Carry in the wrap size recommended by this T-shirt size guide, as well as a size (or more) up and a size (or more) down. A wrapper’s Base Size will likely change over time.



Base Wrap Size 4
some XS


Base Wrap Size 5
XS - S, some M


Base Wrap Size 6
M - L, some S and XL


Base Wrap Size 7
XL - 2XL, some L and 2XL+


Base Wrap Size 8
2XL+, some XL


Base Wrap Size 9+
some 2XL+



Keep in mind that factors such as wrapping a larger child, using a thicker wrap, or a preference for longer tails may require a size up.

title: Reinforced Robin’s Hip Carry
text:
Carry Recipe
Reinforced Robin’s Hip Carry – Base Size – 2 Traditional Sling Passes + Cross Pass

Fold wrap in half lengthwise and place middle in corsage position
Drape tails around back diagonally and thread through loop
Slide baby in both Traditional Sling Passes and tighten
Split wrap and take closest tail over baby and under leg for Cross Pass
Other tail comes down around waist and tie in back

Ruck Tied at Shoulder – Base Size Minus 4 – Ruck Pass + Bunched Torso Pass

Off center Ruck Pass over baby on back
Long tail goes under arm and bunched Torso pass over baby’s legs
TAS

title: Taiwanese Carry
text:
Carry Recipe
Taiwanese – Base Size Plus 1 – 2 Traditional Sling Passes + Torso Pass

Off center Traditional Sling Pass with short tail to hip over shoulder
Long tail spreads across chest under short tail and flips back over open shoulder
Across baby for Traditional Sling Pass
Long tail spreads across chest under short tail and flips back on itself for a Torso Pass

title: Charlie’s Cross Carry
text:
Carry Recipe
Charlie’s Cross Carry – Base Size – Reinforcing Pass + Wiggleproof Pass + Traditional Sling Pass

Reinforced Pass over baby on back
Tail under baby’s leg goes across waist and under baby’s other leg for a Wiggleproof Pass
Long tail goes across chest bunched or spread and across baby for Traditional Sling Pass
Double ring finish/ Shepherd Tie Off/ Knotless with Bunched Pass or Waist Pass

title: About
text:
We built the orignal version of this woven wrap carries wiki in 2014 to make it easier to search for carries by wrap size or other attributes (like, “good for leaners”), featuring carry recipes, carry diagrams, and links to tutorials from the global babywearing community.
After being offline for a few years, we’re working to rebuild the site. Since a lot of our original tutorial links are broken or point to inaccessible, we’re starting fresh, and could use your help to identify the best tutorials around today! Please be patient as we work to get back to being fully functional. If you’d like to recommend a tutorial or a new carry, please reach out to us through Facebook or GitHub issue.

text:

Size 6
4.6m


Size 7
5.2m


Size 8
5.6m


Size 9
6.2m


Size 10
6.6m

title: Front Double Hammock
text:
Carry Recipe
Front Double Hammock – Base Size – 2 Traditional Sling Passes

Spread wrap across back and bring under arms
Two Traditional Sling Passes in front
Flip shoulders by bringing outside rail to the inside
Cross in Back
Can bring tails over traditional sling passes at hips, under and up for knotless
Place baby in both traditional sling passes (Can TUB if not doing knotless)

Front Cross Carry – Base Size – 2 Cross Passes

Bunch wrap across back and bring under arms
2 Cross Passes in front

Can TIF or go over cross passes at hips, under and up for knotless
Slide baby into the cross passes
Tighten and readjust, spread passes, shoulder flip optional

title: Ring Jordan’s Back Carry
text:
Carry Recipe
Ring Jordan’s Back Carry – Base Size – Traditional Sling Pass + Cross Pass + Torso Pass

Traditional Sling Pass over baby on back
Thread both tails through ring
Shoulder flip with under arm tail over same shoulder and across baby for a Cross Pass
Under arm with other tail and Torso Pass over baby
Tails come around, over, and through the ring

Torso Pass (Optional: Fold wrap hot dog style with rails up)
Cross in Back and bring tails over shoulders
Slide baby in pocket
Two Cross Passes, spread or bunched
Tie in Back

title: Wrap Passes
text: A Cross Pass the main Wrap Passes used to build a carry. The wrap spreads over baby on the diagonal with one end under baby’s leg and the other over wrapper’s shoulder. Can also be bunched. A Wiggleproof Pass is a Cross Pass which begins under baby’s leg and is spread up to the wrapper’s opposite shoulder.

title: Wrap Passes
text:
Traditional Sling Pass
A Traditional Sling Pass is one of the main Wrap Passes used to build a carry. The wrap spreads over baby on the diagonal with one end over baby’s leg and under the wrapper’s arm and the other end over the wrapper’s shoulder.

title: Wrap Passes
text:
Ruck Pass, Kangaroo Pass
A Kangaroo Pass or Ruck Pass is one of the main Wrap Passes used to build a carry. The wrap spreads over baby and over both of the wrapper’s shoulders. The term “kangaroo pass” is used when baby is worn on the front or hip; when baby is on the wearer’s back, the pass is considered a “ruck pass.”

title: Wrap Passes
section: Torso Pass, Horizontal Pass, Chest Pass
text:
Torso Pass, Horizontal Pass, Chest Pass
A Torso Pass or Horizontal Pass is one of the main Wrap Passes used to build a carry. The wrap spreads over baby and under both of the wrapper’s arms. Can also be bunched as in RTAS. A Chest Pass is a Torso Pass which spreads across the wearer’s front while baby is worn on the back, as in a Double Hammock.

title: Wrap Passes
text:
Reinforcing Pass
A Reinforcing Pass is a supporting Wrap Pass used to build a carry. The wrap spreads from under the wrapper’s arm across baby diagonally and under baby’s leg. Can be bunched or spread. A reinforcing pass cannot be used to execute a single layer carry.
